New Version of NDBUnit Released: Support for SQLite In Memory DB

Posted by johnvpetersen on November 23, 2009

NDBUnit is a .NET-based library that integrates unit tests and a database. NDBUnit ensures that a database is in a consistent state for each test. You can find the latest binaries here. In a nutshell, NDBUnit provides a mechanism to quickly extract/inject data from/to a database. In other words, as part of your test setup, NDBUnit takes care of the work necessary to insert data into your database so that each test starts in a known good state.

Prior to this new version, the only way you could establish a database connection was by passing a connection string. This meant that the internals of NDBUnit controlled the connection’s life cycle. For databases such as SQL Server, Oracle, SQL Lite (file-based), etc. that are persistent, this is not much of a problem. But what if you wanted to use an in memory database like SQL Lite? Until now, you didn’t have a way to create an instance of SQL Lite, populate the schema and inject data prior to executing a test. The way NDBUnit worked, once the data was inserted into the database, the connection was closed. For in-memory databases, this was a problem. Instead, a connection object whose life cycle was controlled by the calling program  needed to be passed to NDBUnit.

Fortunately, NDBUnit is open source. I approached Steve Bohlen about the problem. We talked about it and soon, I was on my way to creating my first open source contribution. A big thank you to Steve for guiding me through the process!

If you are not familiar with NDBUnit, I would suggest you take a quick detour and review the <a href="http://code.google.com/p/ndbunit/wiki/QuickStartGuide">quick start guide</a>. This guide provides all of the information necessary to get up and running with NDBUnit. What I will concentrate on in this post is how to take the concepts learned in the quick start guide and apply them to a scenario where NHibernate, Fluent NHibernate and the SQL Lite In Memory Database Engine is used.

Walking through the test project

You can find the source code discussed in this post here.

The following third-party .NET libraries are used in this solution:

- NHibernate
- Fluent NHibernate
- SQLite
- NUnit
- And of course – NDBUnit

All off the required libraries are included in the source code.

I followed the steps in the quick-start guide in order to extract the authors table from the pubs database.

<?xml version="1.0" standalone="yes"?>
<MyDataset xmlns="http://tempuri.org/MyDataset.xsd">
  <authors>
    <au_id>172-32-1176</au_id>
    <au_lname>White</au_lname>
    <au_fname>Johnson</au_fname>
    <phone>408 496-7223</phone>
    <address>10932 Bigge Rd.</address>
    <city>Menlo Park</city>
    <state>CA</state>
    <zip>94025</zip>
    <contract>true</contract>
  </authors>

In this project, NDBUnit saved the TestData.xml file in the binDebug folder and that is where the test code will look for the file.

For simplicity, I am illustrating a single entity – the pubs authors table. Here is definition for that entity:

Authors Domain Class
  1. namespace SQLLiteInMemoryTest
  2. {
  3.     public class Authors
  4.     {
  5.         public virtual string au_id { get;  set; }
  6.         public virtual string au_lname { get;  set; }
  7.         public virtual string au_fname { get;  set; }
  8.         public virtual string phone { get;  set; }
  9.         public virtual string address { get;  set; }
  10.         public virtual string city { get;  set; }
  11.         public virtual string state { get;  set; }
  12.         public virtual string zip { get;  set; }
  13.         public virtual bool contract { get;  set; }
  14.     }
  15. }


And here is the mapping class that Fluent NHibernate will use to create the xml-based configuration file NHibernate needs:

Authors Domain Mapping Class
  1. namespace SQLLiteInMemoryTest
  2. {
  3.     public class AuthorsMap : ClassMap<Authors>
  4.     {
  5.         public AuthorsMap()
  6.         {
  7.             Id(x => x.au_id);
  8.             Map(x => x.au_lname);
  9.             Map(x => x.au_fname);
  10.             Map(x => x.phone);
  11.             Map(x => x.address);
  12.             Map(x => x.city);
  13.             Map(x => x.state);
  14.             Map(x => x.zip);
  15.             Map(x => x.contract);
  16.         }
  17.     }
  18. }


If you are new to NHibernate/Fluent NHibernate, I suggest at some point checking out my other <a href="http://johnvpetersen.com/?s=nhibernate">posts</a>. I would also suggest committing time to go through Steve Bohlen’s screen cast series Summer of NHibernate.

The only other code module you need to be concerned with is main.cs. There is one test method called TestSQLiteInMemoryWithConnection(). But before we get to that, let’s take a quick look at the supporting methods:

GetConfiguration() Method
  1. public Configuration Getconfiguation()
  2. {
  3.     return Fluently.Configure()
  4.         .Database(SQLiteConfiguration.Standard.InMemory)
  5.         .Mappings(m => m.FluentMappings.AddFromAssembly(_assemblycontainingmappedtype))
  6.         .BuildConfiguration();
  7. }

The BuildConfiguation() method returns an instance of an NHibernate Configuration which is used by the CreateSessionFactory and BuildSchema Methods. There is a reference to _assemblycontainingmappedtype which refers to a private variable. Fluent NHibernate needs a reference to the assembly that hosts the mapping classes. The origin of the _assemblycontainingmappedtype variable will be discussed at the end of this section.

As you can see, we are using SQLiteConfiguration.Standard.InMemory as our database. Everything we are doing in this example is in-memory. You will find that using the SQLite In-Memory database can greatly speed-up your tests. 

CreateSessionFactory() Method
  1. public ISessionFactory Createsessionfactory()
  2. {
  3.     Configuration configuration = Getconfiguation();
  4.     ISessionFactory sessionfactory = Fluently.Configure()
  5.         .Database(SQLiteConfiguration.Standard.InMemory)
  6.         .Mappings(m => m.FluentMappings.AddFromAssembly(_assemblycontainingmappedtype))
  7.         .ExposeConfiguration(cfg => configuration = cfg)
  8.         .BuildSessionFactory();
  9.  
  10.  
  11.     return sessionfactory;
  12. }


The CreateSessionFactory() method uses an NHibernate Configuation instance to create a SessionFactory instance. The SessionFactory is used to create an NHibernate session. An NHibernate Session contains an instance of IDBConnection. That instance will be passed to NDBUnit for the purpose of loading the data from the XML file.

BuildSchema() Method
  1. public void BuildSchema(ISession session)
  2. {
  3.     var export = new SchemaExport(Getconfiguation());
  4.     export.Execute(true, true, false, session.Connection, null);
  5. }

 

Before data can be loaded into our database, the schema has to be established. The BuildSchema() method accepts a parameter that conforms to ISession. Based on the configuation (the NHibernate XML configuration data) – the necessary SQL DDL statements are passed to the database represented by the session variable. Note – because we are using the Fluent NHibernate library, we don’t need to worry about the specifics of what makes up the XML configuration files.

These three methods are hosted in a class named InMemorySQLiteDB. The InMemorySQLiteDB class has the following constructor:

InMemorySQLLiteDB Constructor
  1. public InMemorySQLiteDB(Assembly assemblycontainingmappedtype)
  2. {
  3.     _assemblycontainingmappedtype = assemblycontainingmappedtype;
  4. }


An assembly reference is passed to the InMemorySQLiteDB constructor. This reference must be the assembly that hosts the mapping classes. Fluent NHibernate uses reflection to scan through the assembly for any class that inherits from ClassMap.

So far, everything done this far has been to get our ORM Library NHibernate up and running. With our foundation in place, we can now write a test that:

- Uses NDBUnit to load up our test data

- Uses Fluent NHibernate to interact with the SQLite In Memory Database

Here is our test fixture:

Test Fixture
  1. namespace SQLLiteInMemoryTest
  2. {
  3.     [TestFixture]
  4.     public class Tests
  5.     {
  6.         private ISession _session;
  7.         private InMemorySQLiteDB _InMemorySQLiteDB;
  8.         private SqlLiteUnitTest _sqlLiteUnitTest;
  9.  
  10.  
  11.         [TestFixtureSetUp]
  12.         public void TestFixtureSetup()
  13.         {
  14.             _InMemorySQLiteDB = new InMemorySQLiteDB(typeof (Authors).Assembly);
  15.         }
  16.  
  17.         [SetUp]
  18.         public void TestSetup()
  19.         {
  20.             _session = _InMemorySQLiteDB.Createsessionfactory().OpenSession();
  21.             _InMemorySQLiteDB.BuildSchema(_session);
  22.             _sqlLiteUnitTest = new SqlLiteUnitTest((SQLiteConnection) _session.Connection);
  23.             _sqlLiteUnitTest.ReadXmlSchema(@"..\..\MyDataset.xsd");
  24.             _sqlLiteUnitTest.ReadXml(@"..\..\Authors.xml");
  25.             _sqlLiteUnitTest.PerformDbOperation(DbOperationFlag.CleanInsertIdentity);
  26.         }
  27.  
  28.         [Test]
  29.         public void testsqliteinmemorywithconnection()
  30.         {
  31.             var x = _session.Get<Authors>("172-32-1176");
  32.             Assert.AreEqual(x.au_lname, "White");
  33.         }
  34.     }
  35. }


For all tests, we only need to create one instance of InMemorySQLiteDB. For each test however, we do need create a new session, build the schema and load the data. Accordingly, these tasks are handled in the [FixtureSetup] and [Setup] attributed methods. 

For each test we run, we have a database with a known good set of data in it. For each subsequent test we run, the [Setup] code will run again, creating a new session, building the schema and populating the database. This is all possible to do now with the In Memory SQLite Database because we can pass a connection object to NDBUnit.

A quick word about <b>MyDataset.xsd</b>.

It turns out that using the VS Dataset Designer is the most efficient way to constuct schema XML necessary to inform NDBUnit about the schema that describes the test data:

Note – NDBUnit still supports a connection string parameter.

That’s about it… I hope you find this new feature in NDBUnit useful!

About johnvpetersen

I've been developing software for 20 years, starting with dBase, Clipper and FoxBase + thereafter, migrating to FoxPro and Visual FoxPro and Visual Basic. Other areas of concentration include Oracle and SQL Server - versions 6-2008. From 1995 to 2001, I was a Microsoft Visual FoxPro MVP. Today, my emphasis is on ASP MVC .NET applications. I am a current Microsoft ASP .NET MVP. Publishing In 1999, I wrote the definitive whitepaper on ADO for VFP Developers. In 2002, I wrote the Absolute Beginner’s Guide to Databases for Que Publishing. I was a co-author of Visual FoxPro Enterprise Development from Prima Publishing with Rod Paddock, Ron Talmadge and Eric Ranft. I was also a co-author of Visual Basic Web Development from Prima Publishing with Rod Paddock and Richard Campbell. Education - B.S Business Administration – Mansfield University - M.B.A. – Information Systems – Saint Joseph’s University - J.D. – Rutgers University School of Law (Camden) In 2004, I graduated from the Rutgers University School of Law with a Juris Doctor Degree. I passed the Pennsylvania and New Jersey Bar exams and was in private practice for several years – concentrating transactional and general business law (contracts, copyrights, trademarks, independent contractor agreements, NDA’s, intellectual property and mergers and acquisitions.).
